author: LuisCruz

description.text:
Update 24/07/2017: Designed and successfully printed a base plate to match the top canopy. All holes line up perfectly with the holes in the Banggood arms (link in comments).
This should also line up with the Wizard drone arms for anyone who damages the top/bottom plates of their Wizard and wants to re-use the arms.

I designed this Drone pod so it would house the DTFC flight controller, a standard FPV camera (HS1177/Runcam Swift etc...), a VTX, FrSky XSR RX and it actually also fits an LC filter in there too!
Uses carbon arms from a Banggood TC-R220 frame and a custom cut plastic bottom plate which seems to be indestructible!
The framework inside the pod is there for support when printing but I believe it's not needed as most printer softwares will input this itself. Can be easily trimmed out.

comments.text:

comments.text:
The case is not very printer friendly. I printed with support and its a pain to remove(lots of waste). the side latches don't match and the front bottom seems to curl up. I've not tweaked any settings and many folks could have different results but ideally, the top case should be made to be printed upside down for no support and I would have liked thicker walls.
I love the look of this case though. would really be interested in seeing you design a case that screws together instead of the latch tabs.
Nice work either way :)

title: MY FAV PI ( raspberry pi 2/3 case )

description.text:
****UPDATED 8.21.17 see notes below

By far my most favorite case to date. Small, compact, and interesting. The only screws required are to mount the 40mm fan in to opening. I used 4 #4 x .375 Phillips flat head sheet metal screws. I still need to c-sink the holes to mount it from the pictures. The bottom is just snap in so you may need to adjust scale if you have any issues but mine was spot on. This is for the people that want to show off their PI and not just hide it :) I can add IO pin cutouts if anyone would like them or the other 2 ribbon cable connections but as I see it this is all you need for displaying your Pi. I did test my hdmi cable and micro usb plugs and there is plenty of clearance. There is a chance some of those more clunky cheap style cables may cause interference but I suggest just get some nicer cables.

I added a version without the fan by request.

11/6/16 - update
I had a request to make the pi easier to install so I uploaded a version that is split along the ports. Make sure if you print the R1 version you print the corresponding R1 top or bottom.

11/10/16 - update
Added 3 versions with IO ports. Ill admit I don't ever use the IO ports so I do not know if it is exactly right so any feedback on these would be great. These are all still the original version tops. I have left the R1 versions as is for people that couldn't snap the pi into the cap.

11/14/16
I use rubber bump-ons on the bottom of all my cases. If you do not have any, do yourself a favor and just order a bunch and keep them on hand. Here is a link to the kind that work the best. link is just to represent product I am not advocating this seller.
https://www.amazon.com/VOVOV-Self-adhesive-Rubber-Bumpons-diameter/dp/B016GWHSBE/ref=sr_1_12?ie=UTF8&qid=1479128622&sr=8-12&keywords=rubber+feet

8/21/17

Added R2 versions that are a more secure snap fit case. Also made more room for the HDMI cable plug. Added logo to the top.

I added 3 files:
my fav pi top snap r2
my fav pi top no fan snap r2
my fav pi bottom snap r2

Any top or bottom that doesn't have R1 or R2 after it can be used in combination. Only R1 parts can be used together. Also only the newly updated R2 parts can only be used together. I strongly suggest using the new R2 parts if you don't need the IO pin exposed.

Printer:

Monoprice Dual ext

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

20 and 80

Notes:

I used 20% infill on the body and 80% infill on the bottom. Just to keep the warp down and to get a good snap together design. I may play with these setting since I would like to refine it best as possible.

comments.text: No - when I upload the files they seam to rotate incorrectly.  You want to print the flat surfaces to your print bed.  So the top would be printed upside down laying flat.  The top of the cover is the first thing printed and work your way to the bottom  " open" edge of the cover as your machine prints..  The bottom is printed, again flat side down, with the bottom of the bottom plate to the print bed and working your way to the top of the bottom plate.

I have included the Sketchup file in case anyone wants to play with the design. The walls are extremely thin, so make sure you have good Skeinforge settings. FYI, the reason for the funky handle is to make it more printable. :) More about this design and other things at my site http://MakerBlock.com
Tea cup post: http://makerblock.com/2010/02/tea-cups/
Print.

Apparently there's this great thing out there for linear motion called a roller pinion. It has all of the advantages of a rack and pinion for simplicity, but it'also precise, has low backlash,is efficient, and quiet. I spent some time trying to figure out how to derive the profile. I believe I'm really close to the right profile. I'm hoping others can help me make it a real thing. It would be nice to use these for anything that needs precise linear movement. I'm thinking that for the rollers you could use smooth rod and some brass tubing from a hobby store (for bushings). Here is some of my reference material.
http://www.ecnmag.com/articles/2011/07/hardware-corner/roller-pinion-tech/ http://www.nexengroup.com/nxn/files/pdf/966650s.pdf

description.text:
This is a design I came up with after purchasing a "fun house" blower from eBay (http://goo.gl/I61q5Z) and designed these two adapters to convert the opening to 1.5 inch. This can be used for laser (CO2/K40 type) fume extraction or run a vacuum table or former. The 170mm fits the larger inlet while the 116mm the outlet and designed receive 1.5 inch PVC connecting pipes.

If you are looking for other K40/eBay CO2 laser parts, we have assembled these lists:

We also did a video on this at https://youtu.be/NIAjOR0v7ws and to learn more about this and our other prints, please visit http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well check out our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIy3DTech.com to learn more about 3D Printing, CNC Machining, and CO2 Laser cutting & engraving! description.text: After years of use and dishwashing, the plastic handles on pot lids degrade in quality. I've copied the design of a pot lid handle of 40 (!) years old that was desintegrating and created it in ABS plastic. Let's see whether it stands the test of time. If not, a few cents of plastic will get me a new one...

I printed it in black ABS, since it needs to withstand high temperatures (~100°C) and alkaline chemicals (dishwasher). It was printed at 245°C with 0.12 mm layer height at 30 mm/s to get a clean finish and prevent delamination. The bed was set at 100°C. Note: I printed it with a brim to prevent warping. Usually that is working great, but this time it was really hard to get it off the bed. Even with coolant spray I couldn't get it off. I ended up ruining my Kapton foil. Point of advice: use a raft or adapt the SCAD file to have a smaller surface area in contact with the bed. Maybe I will make a new version soon.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/2KUEoQqA0Bh

print_settings.Notes:: I left 0.3mm of space between the moving parts. If that's not enough, you probably need to calibrate your printer a bit. Common errors include temp too high (makes strings), filament diameter too small in slicer (makes overextrusion) or belts loose (makes positioning less accurate). The first layer will also have to be quite accurate, as it needs to stick enough to keep the leaves in place, but not so squished that everything fuses together. As anyone who prints my designs knows, these are not for the faint of heart, so don't feel bad if it doesn't work on the first try.

description.text:
I've been wanting to design a non-planar preassembled mechanism for awhile, but it took Prot0typ1cal's Venus Box to inspire me on what to make. That is a beautiful design, but the more I thought about it, the more I thought it should be possible to print without assembly. Combining that spherical box idea with my earlier iris box concept lead to this design.

You can see how it works and how to free it up after printing here: https://youtu.be/-m8uWz-qf7Y

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

I left 0.3mm of space between the moving parts. If that's not enough, you probably need to calibrate your printer a bit. Common errors include temp too high (makes strings), filament diameter too small in slicer (makes overextrusion) or belts loose (makes positioning less accurate). The first layer will also have to be quite accurate, as it needs to stick enough to keep the leaves in place, but not so squished that everything fuses together. As anyone who prints my designs knows, these are not for the faint of heart, so don't feel bad if it doesn't work on the first try.

Believe it or not, pretty much everything in this design adheres to the 45 degree rule, which is why it prints well without supports. If you open this with a program like 3D Builder, you can separate the pieces and see how the internal mechanism is designed. You can also open the source file in OpenSCAD, as it includes an animation of approximately how the pieces move (I'd recommend lowering $fn to 30 so that it doesn't take forever to load).

comments.text:
I printed the remixed 4 leaf version at 60% size and 4 out of 4 came out perfectly and were easy to get moving, so I decided to try one of these. Not wanting to spend 11+ hours printing it, I scaled it to 75%, which was still 7ish hours. First, as has been mentioned numerous times, I dont understand why the bottom ring was made razor sharp and pointy, especially when you have to work so hard to get it to move... I ended up having to wear a glove on one hand, even after my attempts to dull it....
So, after two hours of working at it, I did finally get it moving, but during my attempts, which included a .015" thick, 1/2" wide shim stuck between leaves, I managed to sheer one of the pins... End result it closes just fine, but one leaf doesn't open, i have to manually push it back in.....
Still though, Awesome design... I would definitely try it again (at 100% scale) if a version without the hand shredder were available....
comments.author: dacaur

comments.text: I've printed two of these each on a slightly different heavily modded Monoprice printers. Both printers used the same size .4 nozzle and 200 microns resolution. One of the two was printed in my best PLA I have (AMZ3d) and the other in PLA + (Monoprice). Your readme gave no clues as to how you printed them or what settings you used.
comments.author: dongray55

comments.text: Beautiful but fused. Anet A8; 60 degree bed, 180 deg extruder, 0.1mm resolution, 2.5 mm retraction, jerk control enabled (Cura). Pretty sure cooling flow velocity was pushing the layers together; I disected the part after it didn't work and found that the shells were fused together 180 degrees apart. The only parameter that changes at these locations are the cooling flow characteristics. I am going to print out a new duct that will lower the discharge velocity and direct from 2 different angles 90 degrees or less. Will re-post after.

comments.text: Yeah, I thought, "THAT is the BEST object I've ever seen and I NEED to print one, especially to show my wife that my printer is NOT JUST A TOY." Well, it didn't print so well. It did actually look like it printed excellent, but it didn't move,so the bottom line, it didn't print so well. I ended up deconstructed to see where the failure was as I saw a number of spots that the inner pieces were welded to the inner she'll mostly. I a small section a small part was welded to the outer shell.  Once I had it all apart and saw how small the pivot pins are, I imagined that this would not hold up very well for any real use. It really needs some more robust designing to make it worth my time to print another one. Even tweaking my machine to print it the way it is now, it still wouldn't be good enough to give away or for any real use. If I ever get the time and expertise to modify this, I'll post it and reference my design on this project. Good luck everyone else, but really don't bother printing this the way it is; it uses a lot of filament, takes a long time (12.5hrs.) and even if it moves, it'll be weak where it counts. Ciao for now.

comments.author: cigp

comments.text: Absolutely! I always include a parametric CAD file with my designs: it's the .scad file. It's plain text and compiles the shape in OpenSCAD. You can find the tolerance values in there. However, on a design like this, if it's fusing, making the tolerance larger usually won't help. Generally adjusting temperature, retraction, filament diameter, cooling, z-gap and belt tension will help more. Basically my designs end up as tests of 3D printer calibration and slicer performance.

comments.text: Very cool concept.  I had the same issues that were mentioned by other posters, where the bottom layer fused.  I managed to wreck the bottom when trying to unfuse it (blah).   A couple of quick suggestions:  1) bevel the bottom -- that is, create more space between the pieces on the very bottom .2mm.   This will prevent the bottom layer from fusing (I did this to overcome the same problem on my wire clip).  2) For layer 76 (when printing in .2mm), there's an actual gap between the top and bottom sections.   Different printers will handle this differently (my printer created some artifacts as a result).   Instead of a gap, use a few concentric layers that are exactly .4mm wide (one strand for almost any printer), would allow you to easily run a knife around and cut the bottom from the top.

comments.text: Yeah, sorry, I was feeling inspired by echinoderms and barnacles so it ended up kind of pointy. It sounds like you're having trouble with retraction, which is a very common problem (especially with Bowden tube extruders). The simple answer is increase the retraction distance and sometimes the retraction speed (as long as your extruder can handle it). However, the best fix I find is usually to drop the extruder temperature to where it stops stringing, but still bonds the layers well and extrudes properly at full speed. Every brand and color is a little different. Also, to keep the PLA from warping I point a huge fan at the print. No such thing as too much cooling for PLA.
comments.author: LukeL99

comments.text: Really? I just started printing with PLA. I thought cooling too quickly was bad, so I have my extruder fan turned off for it. My temp is 195. Would you suggest trying a lower temperature, adding the cooling fan, or increasing retraction first?
comments.author: emmett

comments.text: Yeah, cooling is bad for ABS, but great for PLA. I'd start there. Print some side-by-side cylinders and tweak the settings until you're happy with the result. Work your way up to a big print like this one.

description.text:

The case fits so well into the frame, that you don't need any glue or adhesive tape. To fix the lid on the box, I put four holes into it.

The cable leads through the cut-out of the case and the hole of CS2 plate.

Printer:

Malyan M150

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.16mm

Infill:

30%

I used SketchUp 2016 to design this little case. 1st try to do CAD.

Starting with Autodesk and FreeCAD gave me hard time. SketchUp is more intuitive and simple to use.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3I2m2wpAf7Y

Use this puzzle pieces to calibrate the inset surface value in KisSlicer. Other slicers may have a equivalent setting.
  • If pieces don't fit together increase value
  • if pieces fit very loose decrease this value

title: Human proteasome 20S core particle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the structure of the 20S core particle of the human 26S proteasome, based on the structure published by Huang et al. (Nature Structural & Molecular Biology 23, 778–785 (2016) doi:10.1038/nsmb.3273).

The PDB file representing the structure determined by the researchers was edited to remove the 19S regulatory subunits and the surface rendered using Chimera (http://www.cgl.ucsf.edu/chimera/), and exported as an .STL file.

Printer:

ORD Solutions RoVa3D

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Printed using ABS plastic
Acetone vapour polished after removing raft and supports.
Based on the PDB file 5GJR available from the RSCB protein data bank (http://www.rcsb.org/)
Transverse and cross sections through the proteasome core particle were used in a Cell Biology class to illustrate the mechanism of protein recycling in cells.

This model was used in conjunction with first a lecture-based introduction to protein quality control (protein folding, HSPs, ubiquitnylation/degrons, and proteasome regulation), followed by detailed analysis of several recent research papers on the regulation of protein recycling and its relationship to diseases like Parkinson's.

An atomic structure of the human 26S proteasome
Xiuliang Huang, Bai Luan, Jianping Wu & Yigong Shi
Nature Structural & Molecular Biology 23, 778–785 (2016) doi:10.1038/nsmb.3273

Center finder inspired form Woodpeckers MT Center Gauge

See also the bigger version : MTXL Center Gauge

I designed some gauge bars in metric and imperial sizes, ask if you want some other sizes :

  • Imperial : 1/8, 3/16,1/4, 5/16, 3/8, 7/16, 1/2, 9/16, 5/8, 11/16, 3/4, 13/16, 7/8, 15/16, 1"
  • Metric : 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 20, 25mm

You need :

  • 2x Bottom.stl
  • 2x Top.stl
  • 4x Pin
  • 2x Thumb_screw.stl (choose the small or the big model)
  • Gauge bars that you want !
  • 2x M4x16mm hex bolts for the thumb screws
  • 2x M4 nuts by gauge bar

Updates

  • 2016-10-19 : Added 2 new thumbscrew designs
  • 2016-10-21 : Remove old thumbscrews and adjust the diameter of the new ones, they were too big

Accuracy

To get best accuracy as possible, the fittings are tight, it could need a little sanding for a perfect fit, particulary the 'bottom' holes, and the 'top' hole in the middle, where the thumb screw goes.

Don't sand the two other holes in the 'top' part, they are for the pins and have to be very tight to keep the assembly.

The nuts may need to be pushed in the bars with a small hammer or something like that.

http://testingandfixing.tumblr.com/post/66559857817/cooking-chocolate-and-3d-printing

Do ghosts have brains? I believe so!

To scale to the size you need you could print the first layers of the model and test it.
If you can't do a size test, you may print it in the original size. I have tried the ghost costume on some of my friends and its children (7 and 10 years old) and it has worked. If unfortunately the size is too big for a kid, you could glue foami strips inside to get a perfect fit.

It has two holes to add straps. On the ghost costume the straps are placed under the sheet.

Hephestos 2

Thanks,

comments.text:

Easy edit using 3D Builder

comments.text: I posted the photo here. I had trouble slicing the file, there was a gap before the brain started printing. I'll try to fix it by printing a 16mm high 100mm diameter hollow cylinder.

But we will have to wait until the Costume Challenge is closed.
I am so sorry.

title: Cathrin 'triskelon'
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Clathrin heavy & light chain complex - the 'Triskelion' structure that assembles on clathrin-coated pits and drives the formation of endocytotic membrane vesicles.

Printer:

ORD RoVa3D

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

printed using ABS plastic
Acetone vapour polishing after removal of supports and raft

Based on the crystal structure available from the RSCB protein data bank as 3LVG.pdb

Opened in Chimera, orphan fragments deleted, surface rendered and exported as STL.
This model of the clathrin triskelion is used to help illustrate the formation of endocytotic vesicles during our coverage of membrane dynamics in cell biology.
This model is used during both the introductory lecture on membrane dynamics, and later during discussions of recent research papers investigating the molecular mechanisms of endocytosis.

remixed_from.author: CyB
remixed_from.title: BabyNES Raspberry Pi B+ case with vents

title: Baby NES Case for Raspberry Pi 3

description.text:
There are a tons of files so bare with me, did a lot of work on this one. For this remix of the Baby NES Case I used the bottom from jrebeiro and the top and lid from CyB.

NES Bottom:
I made the supports smaller and resized to fit the Pi 3 so that none of the chips would sit on the supports. I also added an LED hole and an led mount to the case. A 3mm led fits perfectly on the mount and can be glued into place. To make removal of the sd card a little easier I engraved a mushroom into the back of the case over the slot. There are three variations: a regular bottom, one with lines engraved, and one for dual color printing. The model with the lines allows for painting of the black lines much easier. The one for dual color printing has the objects spaced exactly 20mm apart. Just separate the objects in your slicing software and move them over exactly 20mm and they will be perfectly aligned.

NES Top:
Added the top half of the mushroom engrave. Didn't like how snug the top was and wanted some wiggle room when putting the bottom and top together so I indented the supports so they aren't completely flush. This allows the case to be put together more straight if it doesn't print exact. I also widened the screw holes a bit. Just like the bottom, there are three variations.

NES Lid:
I reinforced the lid to make it more durable. You can choose from 6 different lids. NES Logo, NES Text, Retropie Logo, Retroberry Logo, Mushberry and a Plain lid. There are also 5 variations of these that are setup for dual color printing. The objects for the lids are exactly 10mm apart so just separate the objects in your slicing software and move them over exactly 10mm and they will be perfectly aligned. The dual color models are flush, the regular models are embossed.

There is also an stl file for an led lense insert. It's tiny, but print this in clear filament and insert into the led hole (I used pliers to squeeze it in). It fits perfectly snug by itself or you can glue it in to make it completely permanent. Looks great and diffuses the led light perfectly.

Worked really hard on this and it looks amazing. Thank you to jrebeiro and CyB for the original models. Let me know if you have any questions comments. Most importantly share your makes!

UPDATE: Added a new plain version of the top that has wider vents.

description.text:
Small container for carrying in-ear headphones.
(e.g. Etymotic HF5) The lock mechanism is by magnets and using two pairs of magnets with opposite polarisation the lid shuts well but pops open when twisting. The design fits a total of four small neodymium magnets (5 mm diameter; 5 mm length) which should be easy to obtain. Magnets should not need glueing. OpenSCAD file included. Credits for logo: http://simpleicon.com/headphone-8.html

Printed with 25% infill and 0.15 mm layer in PLA.
When using OpenSCAD, the headphone.dxf is needed for the logo.

comments.text: Are strong permanent magnets  a good idea next to the magnets in the ear speakers ?
comments.author: listplot

comments.text:
Hi, difficult to say.
In theory not. All magnets are susceptible to taking damage from strong other magnetic fields.
On the other hand, they are not so close and keeping the two earpieces, each having a strong magnet, together may also not be a good idea.
I have my headphones in this box since posting it here and did not notice anything happening. I do not believe this poses a problem.

description.text:
Version 2 of the Grobot is everything you hoped for. It's still a security camera with built-in DVR and environmental sensors that you can monitor via your cell phone from anywhere over a direct secure encrypted peer-to-peer connection with no server in the middle. But now it's smaller, faster, lighter, more accessible, with fewer parts and, well, BETTER!

Full parts list and assembly videos below.

UPDATE 11/03/16
I clicked that button here on the right that says, "Order This Printed" and it turns out their tolerances are better than my Replicator 5th generation with standard settings, so I uploaded a new OpenSCAD file (grobot_v2a.scad) that allows you to adjust the tolerances more easily and also uploaded the two affected parts with a slightly tighter tolerance (grobot_v2_ikbase_3dhubs.stl and grobot_v2_iktop_3dhubs.stl). I also uploaded a file called grobot_v2_assembly.stl but don't print that, it's just illustrative.

Yet another design by me done in Fusion 360. I do not own the image itself, I have only created the 3D model for it. Do print and share, and let me know if you have any questions.

When my arthritis gets bad water bottles are hard to open. So I made these to make my life easier. There are two versions. The one with a single hole called water bottle opener only opens water bottle sized caps. This version works very well and takes very little downward force to grip. The one with two holes called plastic bottle opener has one for water bottle sized caps and soda bottle sized caps. Some water bottles produced by soda companies use the soda sized cap. The soda caps tend to be bulbous so it doesn't grip quite as well and takes a little more effort to grip, bit is still easier then griping with your arthritic hands. This version also does not require supports to print unlike the single hole version. If your only opening water bottles the water bottle version seems to grip just a little better than the plastic bottle version.

comments.text: Does it work pretty well?
comments.author: 21odc01

comments.text:
The water bottle opener seems to work well with all the caps I've tried it on. The soda caps seem to have a bit of an irregular shape, and smaller grooves, so it doesn't catch quite as well. I find adjusting the angle allows the opener to grip a little better.
The holes that grab the caps are all tapered so more you press down the tiger it grips the cap, but usually it doesn't take much force at all to grab (at least for water bottles).
I primarily designed these because of my arthritis, so the handles were big enough that I don't have to close my hand around them. For me they made a huge difference. Without them I can barely get some caps open and it was pretty painful. With these I can easily open bottles with no pain at all.
I wen't shopping for openers before I decided to make my own. Most involved clamp you have to squeeze or really small handles. That wan't going to work for me so I designed my own. My only complaint is the really cheap thin bottles sometimes spill when you use this. Usually I place the opener on top and press down and twist using only my palm. If you push a little too hard you can squirt some water out when you break the seal.
comments.author: 21odc01

description.text: Specialty Molds for One-Off Urethane Parts.  Made with PLA so parts can be demolded by dissolving the PLA.  PLA wall thickness prevents sagging from the heat generated by the Urethane (180degF).  Also making PLA molds to make Silicone Molds for more than one Urethane part.  Silicone cures at room temperature and molds for molds can be thin walled.  PLA dissolving makes life very easy and complex designs can be made.

For Urethane parts, build PLA molds with part as space . . .
For Silicone Molds, build part in PLA with outer skin of PLA to support Silicone . . . 
PLA selected because can dissolve away, especially for hollow parts as flanges and elbows . . .

comments.text: Where does one get urethane or pourable silicon?
comments.author: 1oldclown

comments.text: You can get some hobbyist-quality stuff at http://smooth-on.comsmooth-on.com. The more industrial grade materials, you have to call someone or get quotes for.Â
comments.author: 1oldclown

comments.text: Hi, Pourable Silicone is available on the web from several different suppiers (there is a cottage industry based on Silicone).  You may have a local Polymer Distributor who would gladly offer Silicone and Urethane.  Even large companies such as Wanker and Basf will offer polymers in small containers (1 and 5 gallon).  Search Goggle and it will provide many sources.  We use a local guy here in Florida and he can get the most common to the most exotic materials.  Remember you will need an oven for Urethane for post cure and build up wall thickness to prevent sagging for the mold (also exposed mold walls do better than internal mold wall (which have to be the thickest)) . . .
comments.author: 1oldclown

comments.text: That's amazing! I've been trying to do urethane casting into ABS lately, but have a hard time demolding it. Also, I suspect the urethane polymerization is inhibited by the ABS, but I haven't experimented thoroughly enough to say.
comments.author: joeserdynski

comments.text: About 3 hours away in Central Florida . . . make sure you post what you are doing ! ! !
comments.author: naroom

comments.text: What do you use to disolve PLA?
comments.author: ronthomp

comments.text: Hi, have an old Crock Pot that I heat water to 180degF and just put the part in for about 8 hours (basically overnight while I sleep).  It will then crumble to various degrees depending on thickness.  Just wanting to stay away from heavy Caustics, Acids and chemicals (Urethane is bad enough).  Have to take the time to say that is one excellent looking Dremel Router you made!  Will be making one!
comments.author: ronthomp

comments.text: Thanks! This explains why my Dishwasher silverware rack repair parts won't last in PLA. ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13067http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... ) I finally cut some thin aluminum plate to drop in there.
comments.author: joeserdynski

comments.text: How do you dissolve the PLA parts?
comments.author: imitation

comments.text: Hi,  Hot water (180degF) for about 8 hours.  Didn't want to use any nasty chemicals and have any goo left over.  PLA becomes very brittle and you can just scrap it off.  Really great for those multi-elbow parts and complex shapes.
Do you mean pva instead of pla?
comments.author: joeserdynski

comments.text: Hi, PLA is the one.  Urethane is exothermic and produces lots of heat.  PLA can soften and distort before the urethane part becomes solid (really near solid), so thickness of the wall will dictate any (or lack of) sag.  Throwaway molds are far cheaper (for custom parts) than the usual aluminum or even silicone molds.  PLA is the best because of its rigidity and ease of printing (warpage for ABS) and it came with the printer (!!) . . .
comments.author: scropp

comments.text: oh, ok. I might have to give that a go.
comments.author: joeserdynski

This is a simple PVC filament spool that can hold multiple 1KG or 5LB spools. 
There's nothing to download, but if you make one, please click "I made one!".

This is a simple PVC filament spool that can hold multiple 1KG or 5LB spools. Why spend the afternoon printing and assembling a spool holder when $3-$5 worth of PVC assembles in minutes? Requires:
1 6' Schedule 40 PVC tube
6 L-shaped elbows (slip fit)
2 T corners (slip fit)
hacksaw
Optional: PVC glue, PVC Cutter. Cut 5x1' (~.3m) sections of PVC tube.
Cut 4x2" (~5cm) sections of PVC tube.
Assemble as shown.
I left it entirely unglued - it is pushed together firmly by hand. If you decide to glue it, you can glue the base, but you need to leave at at least one vertical arm and base side unglued so that you can open it to remove the spools. The spool holders sit right on the horizontal PVC tube. I find that this is the right amount of friction so that the spool still rotates freely, yet don't spin on their own, unrolling the filament. Ideally you don't want the spools to rub against each other (creating more friction). As specified above, it can hold 3 x 1KG spools.
Note: I used four-way tees at the upper corner for "expansion", but it's not necessary - the elbows work fine. Possible enhancements: PVC bearings for the spools

Ha, THIS should have won the spool holder contest! Works like a dream. I know it's not 3D printed, but it works SO much better! I've tried 2 other 3D printed models off here with rollers, but they never work.
I modified the above design to better fit my needs. (holds up to x4, 2.2lbs. spools with attachments to add additional rows, a little more stable, able to wrap around my printer and a little branch to hold a roll of blue painters tape for my print plate. I just went out to the local hardware store and purchased everything for a whopping $6.50
Measured everything out, cut it with a saw, assembled within minutes and coated the entire thing in a flat black spray paint. Looks great and functions even better. Currently printing a job with a 5 hr. build time and there's no more jammed filament messages. I love it!
Thank you to the author RRHB for this awesome idea! :)

Power to your shower! Nuff said. :-) Check this out:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_turbine

Print at highest quality possible. Parts are designed for strict tolerances. If your printer is not well aligned, you will get imperfect rotational bodies that will jam rotation. Clean parts carefully and break in rotating parts to make them run smoothly. You will have to cut or sand bumps and edges on the upper and lower flanges where the runner fits tightly in the housing. My first attempt was printed at 0,1mm layer height and 25% infill. The shaft was printed with 100% infill. Housing, runner and cover plate need support structures, all other part printed nicely without support. Support structures "touching build plate" will suffice. The housing part is supported by the internal blades. Some imperfect ceilings because of too big bridging distances are not visible when assembled. The handle prints with the flange layed flat on the build plate. Add brim support to give additional adhesion. The handle is designed for a standard european thread. I think there's only one, don't ask me for the exact size or specification. Just took the measures from the original shower head. Maybe I will add other sizes later, if requested. No gaskets used yet. Parts are fitting tightly enough to let no water spray out. Some water dripping out does not bother me too much. Use M3x10 and M3*16 machine screws. I also tried countersunk head wood screw M3x12 and it works very well. Drill the holes a little bit to get a proper cone fit. Bill of materials: 2 ball bearings 10x6x3
14 screw M3x10
4 screw M3x16
8 nuts M3 Update:
Housing updated. Add missing blade to tangential inlet for uniformly distributed flow

description.text: This is a multi-pieces miniature ideal for wargames. The part need to be glue. If you are confortabled with printing multiple pieces at once, you can use the Tray file that include all the parts. I include 2 versions of the shield, mortar, platform, subplatform and step, one have holes representing battle damages, the other without the holes. You should be able to print all the piece without additional support.

Sugested order of gluing
  • The 2 wheels and the axles
  • The platform on the subplatform. The side with the bolted bar should be on what will be the front (that where will be glue the shield) and the opposite side should be aligned with the bolt of the subplatform. All the textured part of the subplatform should stay visible at the end.
  • The mortar and the 2 mortar suport.
  • The mortar suport and the platform.
  • The axle under the base. Leave around the diameter of the axle before the border.
  • The platform and subplatform on the base, the bottom of the subplatform should fit on the 2 peg of the base and the platform on the front part of the base.
  • The shield on the front of the platform.
  • The step on the platform, the side where there no bolt.
  • The crank on the mortar suport, the side of the step.

description.text: I created a 20' 3D printed dual lane race track for students to use for K-12 STEAM projects in my school district. Students can design, print, and race their 3D printed cars on the track or you can have students build their cars out of cardboard and use washers to race against each other. Also, students will learn about forces and motion, friction, engineering, data analysis, and math application throughout the whole process. I have students video record with a timer app and record the times through each section of the track. Students will then graph their results and find ways to increase their speed and decrease their track times.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used PLA to print all of the parts.

Step 1: Print 42 main track sections
Step 2: Print 1 Down Track Curve
Step 3: Print 4 Wooden Rod Base Plates
Step 4: Print 4 of the Track Down Ramp Supports
Step 5: Take a file and file down all of the T joints on all of the track pieces.
Step 6: Assemble the main track sections into 6 connected pieces.
Step 7: Use #8-32 x 1-1/2 in overbuilt flat head Phillips screws and #8-32 machine screw nuts to tighten the track pieces together.
Step 8: When you connect the down curve piece break off the T joint on the main track piece ( use large pliers) and loosely connect the curve.
Step 9: Buy a large 1-1/4 wooden dowel rod from HomeDepot and have it cut into the following measurements: 18 inches, 41 inches, 64 inches, and 87 inches.
Step 10: Attack the Down Ramp Support Pieces onto the main track sections and carefully assemble the track from the bottom up. I only used 5 main track pieces when I attached them to the curve piece at the bottom.

I used Onshape to design this race track. I have a link which will allow any user to copy, edit, and download the files for the track. If you want to modify it please use the link below and create a free OnShape account.

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/bc3b8dab5fc64add49408014/w/3573fd1df50ea19b35d5906f/e/87f03f2a4acd90b5d841caf7
NGSS

I created a 20' 3D printed dual lane race track for students to use for K-12 STEAM projects in my school district. Students can design, print, and race their 3D printed cars on the track or you can have students build their cars out of cardboard and use washers to race against each other. Also, students will learn about forces and motion, friction, engineering, data analysis, and math application throughout the whole process. I have students video record with a timer app and record the times through each section of the track. Students will then graph their results and find ways to increase their speed and decrease their track times.

Lesson Plan Step 1: have student measure the track with calipers and use cardboard, hot glue, washers, and nails to construct a prototype.
Step 2: students race their cars, record their track times with video timer app on the smartphone or tablet.
Step 3: students will then use either Tinkercad or Onshape to design their car bodies, wheels, and axles.
Step 4: students will then race their cars, experiment with different weight settings, different wheel diameters and thicknesses, and chart their data on a spreadsheet to find the best possible design.
Step 5: students will test different weight locations and they are limited to 150 gram weight setting.
Step 6: encourage students to design one wheel, two wheel, three wheel, and four wheel cars.
PLA Filament, Calipers, 3D Printer, Screwdriver, 100 #8-32 1-1/2 inche screws, drill, wooden dowel rod, wooden base plates, and 100 #8-32 machine nuts.

• 3D Modeling
  • 3D Printing
  • Geometry
  • Math and science
  • Engineering
  • Data Analysis
2 Weeks-9 Weeks

title: D-Bot Print Carriage Front w/Proximity Mount

description.text:
This is my re-mix of the '1-Print_Carriage_Front' for the D-Bot that includes a mount for a 12mm inductive proximity sensor.

A few quick comments:
The D-Bot really doesn't need auto-bed leveling. I just added it to mine simply to have all the bells and whistles.

I designed this to fit using the Mr. Metric 5mm carriage bolts. In theory, all M5 'Socket Head Cap Screws' should have the same head height. You may have issues if the head height on your M5 carriage bolts are taller than normal. If anybody has a problem let me know and i'll make the sensor stick out farther. My goal was to make everything nice, tight and compact.

Also.. I have an E3D v6 hotend, It may not fit with anything else. YMMV.

description.text:
This thing is triple remix based on my last one "ZMR 250 landing foot for 1806 motor guard" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1743198 (Aug 29, 2016) combined with "high zmr motor guard" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1417558 by "Heimscheisser" (Mar 15, 2016) and "ZMR motor savers/guards" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:984836 by "Judar" (Aug 26, 2015).

I have merged all designs so both the high and low guards include now a sphere or a cone landing foot, all in one piece/guard that is attached directly to the arm of the frame using the same screws of the motors. The base of these guards is now higher (3 mm) providing more robustness, so I recommend to use at least M2x8 screws depending on the high of the arms.

Because of complexity of the piece, supports are needed for printing, so the pieces are rotated. After the process you should use a cutter to remove the support carefully.

The desings are for the 1806 motor and there are cutted versions as the pieces of my previous remix. In addition you can choose among a lower guard ("Judar" design) and a higher guard ("Heimscheisser" design).

The files available to download are:

Cone version:

  • zmr250_landing_foot_cone_with_low_motor_guard_cutted_sxs.stl
  • zmr250_landing_foot_cone_with_high_motor_guard_sxs.stl
  • zmr250_landing_foot_cone_with_high_motor_guard_cutted_sxs.stl

Sphere version:

  • zmr250_landing_foot_sphere_with_low_motor_guard_sxs.stl
  • zmr250_landing_foot_sphere_with_low_motor_guard_cutted_sxs.stl
  • zmr250_landing_foot_sphere_with_high_motor_guard_sxs.stl

title: Google Pixel and Pixel XL Phone

description.text:
I wanted to get a feel for how the new Google Pixel would feel in my pocket so I quickly modeled both the Pixel and Pixel XL. The dimensions were taken from Google's Pixel website, although the thickness is shown as a range (0.2-0.3" for the Pixel and 0.2-0.34 for the XL). I guess the thickness will vary on something, so these are modeled with the max thickness shown. The screen size should be accurate (aspect ratio is 1.778, based on the advertised resolution of 1440x2560).

As for the bevels, chamfers, and buttons, I just eyeballed them from the photos online. They are probably not accurate. I will upload the Inventor 2017 files as well if someone wants to improve on them.

Added a pdf of sample screens you can print out and put on the front to give you an idea of how the screen size differs.

comments.text: i own the 5 inch phone and it feels amazing. though really slippery without a case.
comments.author: newbpwnr

comments.text: Quick FYI on the varying thickness: the Pixel is actually tapered from the top to the bottom. It's barely noticeable, but it's there, and that's how they got away with not having a camera bump. For each phone, the largest thickness listed is at the top of the phone, and the smallest is at the bottom.

comments.text: I was about to do exactly this.  I have a Nexus 5 right now and wanted to see how much bigger the Pixel is.  It seems like it wouldn't be much, but numbers are not the same as having something to hold.  Thanks!

comments.author: xeruvim

comments.text: You probably found an answer to this already but Igus "bearings" are a special material bushing where the material extrudes it's own lubrication as it wears.  The LM8UU bearings have small balls that roll along the rod in a linear fashion to move the bearing across the rod.  These bushings are similar to the Igus style but do not have the plastic lubrication.
comments.author: xeruvim

comments.text: I think perhaps he's referring to the two files available: LM8UU_igus_style_dia8.3.stl vs LM8UU_dia8.3.stl.  I'm a little curious too about this.  Comparing the models in Simplify 3D, it appears they're almost the same except the non-Igus ones have channels going perpendicular to the main channels.

comments.author: obor

comments.text: Nylon is very good material to use in this scenario. Nylon is used in a lot in plastic bearing applications already. It is low friction and self-lubricating (in that it needs no lubrication). It also wears at a low rate and is inexpensive, so from a practicality standpoint, it's a major win. Always keep an extra set printed for maintenance!
comments.author: obor

comments.text: If you make them too long then you will have more friction! Also I don't recommend oiling them. You may end up with layer separation if the oil becomes absorbed. Also if you use oil it will attract dust and particles. Will end up possibly acting like more of an abrasive. If you buy the IGUS type they are impregnated with lubricant. I am gonna try this print and I will repost my results....if I remember. Lol.
comments.author: ZombieGoat

comments.text: OMG the noise reduction in my Anet A8 is amazing. I can't recommend this mod strongly enough if your cheap Chinese bearings grind and rattle do give these a try.
